FROSH SMOKER ON FEB. 15
After repeated postponements,
the Freshman Class has decided to
hold its smoker on the fifteenth of
February. Although a place has
not been definitely selected, the affair will not be held on the campus.
President Niner has requested all
freshmen possessed with entertaining ability to make their talent
known to the committee in charge,
so that a purely "local" program
can be offered on the fifteenth. If
the response can be used as a criterion, the smoker will not be lacking in varied amusement. The committee expects Vernon Winchester
to be toastmaster at the gathering,
and is relying on a vocal rendition
by the class president.
The men in charge are Schwinn,
chairman Lord, Hayel, Robinson.
Meredith and Steinwald.

The following was suggested to me by the celebration at
a New Year's Eve dance, 1923-1924, and the sentence from
Twelfth Night, Act V, Sc. 1, line 165:
Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave
I have travell'd but two hours.
The clocks tolled twelve with, many a noisy roar,
The whistles blew, and shots from pistols broke
The death-like silence of the night; awoke
All things with tumult growing more and more.
The crowd of dancers throng-;ng o'er the floor,
Hurrahed with thoughtless joy at every stroke
By which the bells and clocks alike provoke
This happiness for nineteen twenty-four.
In my snug corner where I watched this throng,
My thoughts were of a vastly different strain.
With all their laughter and with all their song,
They could not raise my mind from this refrain:
"Poor fools! Do they not know that in this breath,
Another milestone has been passed towards Death?"

the response can be used as a criterion, the smoker will not be lacking in varied amusement. The committee expects Vernon Winchester

and is relying on a vocal rendition
by the class president.

chairman Lord, Hayel, Robinson.

By I. W. Russell, '24
The following was suggested to me by the celebration at
a New Year's Eve dance, 1923-1924, and the sentence from
Twelfth Night, Act V, Sc. 1, line 165:
Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave
I have travell'd but two hours.
The clocks tolled twelve with, many a noisy roar,
The whistles blew, and shots from pistols broke
The death-like silence of the night; awoke
All things with tumult growing more and more.
The crowd of dancers throng-;ng o'er the floor,
Hurrahed with thoughtless joy at every stroke
By which the bells and clocks alike provoke
This happiness for nineteen twenty-four.
In my snug corner where I watched this throng,
My thoughts were of a vastly different strain.
With all their laughter and with all their song,
They could not raise my mind from this refrain:
"Poor fools! Do they not know that in this breath,
Another milestone has been passed towards Death?"
